title: Crabgrass Confidence Interval
question_text:
Rob applied preventative herbicide/fertilizer to stop crabgrass in his lawn. He applied $4$ levels of treatment, each to $4$ sections of his lawn at random, and recorded the change in crabgrass plants per square meter. The data is given below: Regression analysis was performed and a $98\%$ confidence interval for the slope of the true regression line of change in crabgrass on treatment was constructed.
$98\%$ Confidence Interval: $ (-1.134, -0.8364)$
Interpret the meaning of this interval in context.

choices.text: We are 98% confident that the mean change in crab grass plants per square meter is between −1.134 and −0.8364 plants.

solution:
Solution

A level C
confidence interval means that if the experiment were repeated many times under the same methods, approximately C%
of the resulting intervals would capture the true parameter in question.

Thus, we can say that we are 98%
the interval from −1.134
to −0.8364
crabgrass plants per square meter captures the slope of the true regression line relating change in crabgrass and herbicide/fertilizer.

So, Choice 'E' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect.

This incorrect interpretation is made as if the parameter is a population mean. The inference procedure is about slope which involves both variables, change in crab grass and herbicide/fertilizer applied.

Choice 'B' is incorrect.

This incorrect interpretation assumes that true regression slope depends on the upper and lower bounds of the confidence interval.

Since the confidence interval is a combination of the slope point-estimate and the margin of error, the process used can be expected to generate intervals within which the true slope lies approximately
